#Build a plot as a list
```{r}
library(plotly)
fig = list(
  data = list(
    list(
      x = c(1, 2, 3),
      y = c(1, 3, 2),
      type = 'bar'
    )
  ),
  layout = list(
    title = 'A Figure Specified By R List',
    plot_bgcolor='#e5ecf6', 
         xaxis = list( 
           zerolinecolor = '#ffff', 
           zerolinewidth = 2, 
           gridcolor = 'ffff'), 
         yaxis = list( 
           zerolinecolor = '#ffff', 
           zerolinewidth = 2, 
           gridcolor = 'ffff')
  )
)
# To display the figure defined by this list, use the plotly_build function
plotly_build(fig)
```

```{r}

           zerolinecolor = '#ffff', 
           zerolinewidth = 2, 
           gridcolor = 'ffff'), 
         yaxis = list( 
           zerolinecolor = '#ffff', 
           zerolinewidth = 2, 
           gridcolor = 'ffff')) 
fig
```

```{r}
library(plotly)
data(iris)

fig <- plot_ly(data = iris, x = ~Sepal.Width, y = ~Sepal.Length, color = ~Species, 
               type = "scatter", mode = "markers")%>%
  layout(title="A Plotly Figure", legend=list(title=list(text='species')),
         plot_bgcolor='#e5ecf6', 
         xaxis = list( 
           zerolinecolor = '#ffff', 
           zerolinewidth = 2, 
           gridcolor = 'ffff'), 
         yaxis = list( 
           zerolinecolor = '#ffff', 
           zerolinewidth = 2, 
           gridcolor = 'ffff'))
fig
```

#Plotting markers and lines
```{r}
library(plotly)

trace_0 <- rnorm(100, mean = 5)
trace_1 <- rnorm(100, mean = 0)
trace_2 <- rnorm(100, mean = -5)
x <- c(1:100)

data <- data.frame(greg = x, trace_0, trace_1, trace_2)

fig <- plot_ly(data, x = ~greg)
fig <- fig %>% add_trace(y = ~trace_0, name = 'trace 0',mode = 'lines')
fig <- fig %>% add_trace(y = ~trace_1, name = 'trace 1', mode = 'lines+markers')
fig <- fig %>% add_trace(y = ~trace_2, name = 'trace 2', mode = 'markers')

fig
```

#Plotly works with ggplot!

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(mdsr)
library(babynames)
Beatles <- babynames %>%
  filter(name %in% c("John", "Paul", "George", "Ringo") & sex == "M") %>%
  mutate(name = factor(name, levels = c("John", "George", "Paul", "Ringo")))
beatles_plot <- ggplot(data = Beatles, aes(x = year, y = n)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = name), size = 2)
beatles_plot
```

```{r}
library(plotly)
ggplotly(beatles_plot)
```

#We can also do interactive tables!
#With datatable!
```{r}
library(DT)
datatable(Beatles, options = list(pageLength = 10))
```

#Dygraphs
```{r}
library(dygraphs)
Beatles %>% 
  filter(sex == "M") %>% 
  select(year, name, prop) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = name, values_from = prop) %>%
  dygraph(main = "Popularity of Beatles names over time") %>% 
  dyRangeSelector(dateWindow = c("1900", "1980"))
```

#In class exercises
```{r}
ins <- read.csv("/Users/gregorymatthews/Dropbox/Public/inspections_clean.csv")

#Make an interactive plot that shows pass rate by month with inspection type represented by color.  
#Repeat this for a dygraph
#Class: Come up with an interesting plot we can make and we'll all make it together.  Ask class for an idea.  


#Create a plot with day of the week on the x-axis and the y-axis is number of inspections.  Line graph.  Stratified by facility type: restaurant, school, grocery store, other.  Make it interactive!
ins <- read.csv("/Users/gregorymatthews/Dropbox/Public/inspections_clean.csv")

sub <- ins %>% select(inspection_date,facility_type)  %>% mutate(facility_type = case_when(facility_type %in% c("bakery","catering","gas station","hospital","liquor","long term care") ~ "other", .default = facility_type), 
dayofweek = wday(as.Date(inspection_date),abbr = TRUE, label = TRUE),
dayofweeknum = wday(as.Date(inspection_date),abbr = TRUE, label = FALSE)) %>% group_by(facility_type,dayofweek, dayofweeknum) %>% summarise(n = n()) 
               
g <- ggplot(aes(x = dayofweek, y = n, color = facility_type), data = sub) + geom_point() + geom_line(aes(x = dayofweeknum, y = n, color = facility_type), data = sub)

ggplotly(g)




```


```{r}
ins <- read.csv("/Users/gregorymatthews/Dropbox/Public/inspections_clean.csv")
library(lubridate)
ins$inspection_date <- as.Date(ins$inspection_date)
ins <- ins %>% mutate(month = month(inspection_date), year = year(inspection_date))
ins$year_month <- as.Date(paste(ins$year, ins$month,"01",sep = "-"))

summ <- ins %>%  group_by(year_month, inspection_type) %>% summarize(pass_rate = mean(results %in% c("Pass","Pass w/ Conditions")))

g <- ggplot(aes(x = year_month, y = pass_rate, colour = inspection_type), data = summ) + geom_line()
g

ggplotly(g)


```
